Award.AwardTitle: Dissertation Research: Drivers of community composition, species interactions, and gene flow in urban landscapes
Award.AbstractNarration:
Animals contribute to the pollination of 90% of all plant species; therefore they are essential for maintaining healthy ecosystems. Of these animals, bees are some of the most effective and important pollinators of wild plants and their service as pollinators to agricultural systems is worth hundreds of billions of dollars each year. In addition to the familiar domesticated European honeybee, there are at least 20,000 other species of wild bees worldwide. Many of these wild bee populations, however, are declining in number due to human-caused landscape changes, including urbanization. This research explores how urban landscapes alter the types of bee species found in cities, how urban bees use and pollinate native plants, and how different-sized bee species move through urban areas. As a part of this project, researchers will make recommendations to land owners to promote healthy pollinator communities. In addition, this project will enrich the scientific community by employing college and high school students from underserved communities as research assistants.

The study will investigate the impacts of urban land use patterns on plant-pollinator interactions using a network analysis approach. The plant-pollinator networks across an urban gradient will be developed through observations of floral visits by bees and the examination of pollen diversity collected from bees found along a gradient of urbanization (40 sites ranging in urban coverage from 0-100 %). As previous observations indicate that urbanized areas contain fewer food resources than rural areas, the researchers predict that bees at urban sites may visit a greater variety of floral species, whereas bees in rural sites may be more specialized in their food choices. To investigate dispersal and colonization patterns within urban landscapes, this study will also examine the genetic make-up of two closely related carpenter bee species. These species are similar in nesting behavior, but vary in size and thus their dispersal potential. The researchers predict that the larger species (Xylocopa virginica) will show fewer genetic signatures of population isolation (ex. inbreeding) than the smaller species (Ceratina strenua) because they can disperse farther through urban areas. Ultimately, results from this study will allow inferences on how pollinators can persist in urban landscapes over time.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wild native bee species provide the majority of pollination services to wild and agricultural plants, which is necessary for plant fruit set and reproduction. Despite the importance of bee pollination for this crucial ecosystem function, very little is known about how land-use (such as urbanization or agricultural landscape change) drives native bee community composition/ biodiversity, and how bees can move across these landscapes to nest and reproduce. Anthropogenic land use can dramatically alter historical landscape structure, leaving behind isolated remnant habitats, resulting in long distances between suitable habitat patches that may prevent the dispersal of reproductive individuals. Measurements of genetic structure can reveal how organisms disperse through altered landscapes, and what types of land use may facilitate or impede wildlife movement at multiple scales. 

We had two goals in this research: 1) investigating land-use impacts on native bee communities, including measuring the number of bees and bee species across a gradient of urbanization, and 2) investigating land-use impacts on the population genetic structure of wood-nesting bee species. This research is among the first to specifically incorporate investigations of land-use on native bee communities at both local and regional scales, and the first to investigate land-use effects on wood-nesting bee populations.  

For our first goal, we collected bees and land-use data across 40 study sites within a ~350 km corridor from Central to Northeastern Texas, spanning two of the fastest growing cities in the U.S. We found that levels of regional land-use differentially impacted bee abundance and diversity depending on local habitat management (Ballare et al. 2019, Ecological Applications). While bee diversity levels in natural grassland sites were similar across the urban/natural landscape gradient, agriculture sites (farms and community gardens) did not support as diverse of a bee community when located in highly developed areas as compared to rural agriculture. These indicate that bee conservation practices depend critically on land-use interactions across multiple spatial scales. We recommend that farms located in rural areas may be able to leverage adjacent seminatural habitat fragments to augment wild bee communities and pollination service, while community gardens and farms with less seminatural landscape context should focus on efforts to augment local habitat resources in order to support bee abundance and diversity in these areas, including providing native floral forage and bare, un-mulched soil for below-ground bee nesting habitat.

For our second goal, we investigated if urban and agricultural areas were a barrier to or facilitated movement and exchange of genes in the eastern carpenter bee Xylocopa virginica across a ~450 km area in Central and Northern Texas. X. virginica is a large bee commonly found in both urban and rural areas across Southern and Eastern North America, and nests above-ground in both man-made and natural wooden materials.  Although urban and agricultural landscapes have been shown to be significant barriers of dispersal in other large-bodied bees that nest underground, by measuring levels of genetic relatedness throughout our study area, we found that X. virginica disperses readily through human-altered landscapes. We hypothesize that this is due to both increasing numbers of potential nesting sites in human-altered areas, as well as by human-mediated dispersal through movement of firewood or lumber. This is the first study to show that urban land-use can facilitate bee movement.

Additionally, by incorporating mentorship, public outreach, and education into research, we advanced public understanding of pollinator biodiversity and biology, and promoted evidence-based pollinator conservation recommendations. Most of our collecting sites are well-known urban farms, community gardens, and public parks, and we have compiled site-specific outreach materials to be displayed for farm visitors, community gardeners, and park visitors that include recommendations for encouraging native pollinator habitat. We have closely mentored at least one undergraduate student during the majority of long semesters and every summer throughout the course of this project (a total of 15 students, including 7 minorities and 11 women).  8 of these students have completed work resulting in research symposium presentations, and one resulting in a co-authored manuscript for publication (Ballare et al. 2017, Rhodora).
